The title indicates that it’s going to be some kind of Kurosawa-esque Samurai action film, but instead we have something closer in tone to an Ozu, Mizoguchi or Ichikawa period ‘road’ drama about family and societal class. If you go into this film with those expectations in mind, then your bound to enjoy its pleasant blend of drama and comedy filled with interesting characters, and solid writing that manages to draw you into its world before building up to an electric and emotionally intense final act.

Lady Musashino (1951)

Directed by Kenji Mizoguchi

Continuing with the 1950s Japanese theme, it seemed only right to check out another one of the master filmmaker Kenji Mizoguchi’s works. The last bunch of Mizoguchi films that I’d seen had already been period pieces set mostly in the Samurai era, so it was refreshing to see a more contemporary film by him, in the form of the post-war melodrama The Lady of Musashino. As always, Mizoguchi’s direction is fantastic and the narrative themes of sexual politics and family strife within the cultural ‘sea change’ of post-war Japan are brought to fruition through gorgeous camerawork, eye-catching compositions, impressive long-takes and captivating performances. This short – but by no means minor – work also manages to cleverly subvert the more cliché-ridden romanticised notions of tragedy usually associated with this kind of film, during its last act, which actually genuinely ends up becoming emotionally powerful instead of overly melodramatic.

Sound of a Mountain (1954)

Directed by Mikio Naruse

I managed to get quite lucky in finding a reasonably priced copy of the long out of print Eureka Masters of Cinema boxset of Mikio Naruse’s later films. As the 1954 feature Sound of the Mountain was regarded by the director as his personal favourite of his own works, it seemed like the next logical place to go with exploring his filmography. In typical Naruse fashion it explores a quiet intimate narrative concerning familial issues and sexual politics in a post-war setting. The story focuses primarily on the close kinship between a young woman and her father-in-law who live in the same house with the woman’s neglectful and unfaithful husband and his mother. It’s a beautifully constructed work that manages to stray away from the usual trappings and clichés of melodrama to display an honest portrayal of inner turmoil created through infidelity and ineffectual family bonds. The subtle technicality of the film is fantastic too with some excellent compositions that manage to show you just what a character is thinking, without having to actually explain it.

Floating Weeds (1959)

Directed by Yasujiro Ozu

It’s kind of criminal that I’ve gotten as deep as I have into Japanese cinema only having watched one Ozu film (especially since I own 27 of his works across my DVD and Blu-ray collection), so it’s certainly time to start rectifying that. I started my journey into Ozu’s films nearly three years ago with his most highly regarded work Tokyo Story; I was a little taken back by just how gentle and family centric the film was – with very little drama and a style punctuated by extreme minimalism. When I realised the rest of his films were very similar, I decided I wasn’t quite ready for ‘that sort of film’ yet, when there’s still so many samurai flicks and ghostly period dramas to explore. Tokyo Story‘s style has frequently played in my mind though, so it obviously had a subconscious effect on me… anyway, I must degrees.

Floating Weeds is one of Yasujiro Ozu’s much later works (which also happens to be a remake of one of his earliest works) that transposes his minimalist black and white style into gorgeous Technicolor. One thing that cannot be denied about this film is just how damn beautiful every frame and composition is, thanks to his trademark low angle static shots being punctuated with a feverish and dreamlike vibrancy. The film mostly centres on a travelling troupe of stage actors and the family dynamic therein, as well as the relationship between the head of this troupe and a mother and her son living in the town that there show is currently playing at. The film’s themes seem to centre on class issues, which expose how rather abhorrent the main character turns out to be. It’s a very well made film that will completely draw you into its perfectly framed world, if you have the patience to let it. The film’s highlight for me was a magnificently shot shouting match on opposite sides of a street in the pouring rain.

Desert Hearts (1985)

Directed by Donna Deitch

This 1950s set adaptation of novel titled Desert of the Heart, is a beautifully nuanced examination of the blossoming romantic relationship developing between an older regimented straight woman and a younger carefree lesbian, as well as the prying eyes of the bigoted individuals who surround them. With a great soundtrack, stunning locale, impassioned performances and an assured direction from Donna Deitch, everything all adds up to a winning combination here. It’s easily up there as one of my favourite discoveries of the year.

The Comfort of Strangers (1990)

Directed by Paul Schrader

The BFI blu-ray with its Gustav Klimt-esque cover art was too enticing not too pick up when I saw it going cheap in a charity shop (along with a Criterion blu release of Orson Welles F for Fake… yes please!). A very early 90s adaptation of an Ian McEwan novel, The Comfort of Strangers tells the story of a couple holidaying in Vienna in an attempt to work out their relationship issues. They soon fall prey to the obsessions of a mysterious stranger, played in an effortlessly creepy manner by Mr Christopher Walken. Helen Mirrem and the late Natascha Richardson also deliver some decent performances, which, along with the smooth pacing, gorgeous locale and playful eroticism, end up being some fine ingredients to this psychological psychosexual treat.

The Wayward Cloud (2005)

Directed by Tsai Ming-Liang

This Taiwanese flick might be one of the most bizarre mixtures of styles and genres committed to film in recent times. Moving from scenes of slow-burning almost dialogue-less romanticised nothingness, to big bold ‘Bubsy Berkly’ stylised musical numbers to behind-the-scenes segments of a hardcore pornography filming crew (occasionally performing less than savoury acts with watermelons…). The way the film drifts between these styles and scenes creates odd moments of dreariness bleeding into bizarre fantasy, and moments of playful romantic eroticism giving way to ugly gratuity. The film is shot really well and there are some fantastic moments amidst some of the slow-burning stuff. The musical numbers are by and large really entertaining too… however the final scene in this film is a bit fucked up in a rather mean-spirited way which almost derails all the good points about the film and might leave you with a sour taste in your mouth as the credits roll… It’s definitely the very definition of a mixed bag.

A Wife to be Sacrificed (1974)

Directed by Masaru Konuma

This 1970s ‘Pinky’ exploitation flick has been sitting on my shelf for a fair while now since acquiring it amidst a binge of obscure Japanese oddities. The story concerning a women’s ex-husband kidnapping her and forcing her to fall back in love with him through a variety of sexual torture games, reminded me ever so slightly of Pedro Almodovar’s oddball erotic drama Tie Me Up, Tie Me Down… but they couldn’t be further apart in tone. This film manages to get a whole lot more disturbing at times since the male lead is a lot less likable than Almodovar’s Spanish counterpart. It manages to straddle the line at times relatively well between artfulness and fetishism with the way certain scenes are shot, but it’s not quite in the same calibre as In the Realm of the Senses. Recommended only for seasoned fans of 70s Japanese sexploitation.

Two from Suzuki

Youth of the Beast (1963) / Yumeji (1991)

Directed by Seijun Suzuki

Seijun Suzuki’s directs this supremely fun 60s crime flick with a keen eye for interesting set design and entertaining set-pieces. Backed up by a neat narrative dynamic that recalls Kurosawa’s Yojimbo – in its protagonist playing both sides for fools to achieve his own ends – Youth of the Beast satisfyingly blends absurdity and sensationalism to milk the most out of its pulpy premise with its tongue in its cheek and a wink to the audience. If you liked Branded to Kill or Tokyo Drifter, then chances are high that you’ll dig this.

In this third part of Suzuki’s thematic ‘Taisho’ trilogy we are treated to a very strange and surreal narrative concerning a painter, the titular Yumeji. It’s a truly bizarre work and, out of the three films in the trilogy, makes the least sense… but I still really liked it. In a way that manages to be ‘even-more-Lynchian-than-David-Lynch’ Suzuki constructs a unique dreamscape of gothic eroticism through his colourful compositions that frame his nightmarish scenes. It’s not for everyone, but if you’re particularly in the mood for a period-set Japanese Twin Peaks, then you should be right at home with this piece of stunningly beautiful nonsense.

Fist of Fury (1972)

Directed by Lo Wei

It’s been close to twenty years since I last saw Fist of Fury – my first taste of Bruce Lee – and I managed to surprisingly remember a fair amount of it through my hazy nostalgic memory of a very late night channel 4 viewing. Between this, The Crow and a host of Bruce and Brandon Lee documentaries, I developed a small obsession with martial arts cinema at the age of 8 or 9… now at the age of 27 I’ve started to get back into it with a vengeance.

Between Lee’s mind-bending displays of martial arts mastery and the pulpy – but excellently paced – filmmaking craft, Fist of Fury manages to stand tall as one of Hong Kong cinemas most riotously entertaining and action flicks of the 70s.

Deadly Face-Chomping Aliens, Supernatural Serial Killers and a Whole Lot of Eastern Exploitation – My September & October 2018 Film Round-Up

Perhaps a little more belated than usual, but I have finally gathered by musings together on all the good, bad, odd and certifiably insane films I’ve discovered over the past few months. First up is my September and October viewings which is comprised largely of cult exploitation and sleaze from Hong Kong and Europe (plus a few less crazy flicks thrown in for measure).

The Hong Kong Exploitation Stuff:

The Oily Maniac (1976)

Directed by Ho Meng-Hua

If marks could be given for title alone, then The Oily Maniac would be a very hard film to top… fortunately though, it is a bizarre and entertaining enough film to live up to its title’s ludicrous promise. In typical Shaw Brothers fashion, black magic shenanigans and supernatural horror mingle with modern day gang violence and inner city grime to create a blackly comic cult gem. It’s not for everyone, but if you’re a fan of similar Hong Kong horror flicks and gooey low-budget body horror, then there’s a chance you may dig this gleefully mad oddity about a crippled criminal lawyer‘s clerk who turns into a super-strength mass of sentient tar by night. The scenes of the titular character running across rooftops, dropping in on hospital operating theatres to mess shit up and chasing down triads were hugely entertaining to watch.

Rick-Oh [Story of Ricky] (1991)

Directed by Lam Nai-Choi

I had heard that this was one of the more mind-melting of the 90s Hong Kong ‘CAT III’ pictures, due to its bonkers blending of genres and ideas (including prison film, martial arts, body horror and splatter)… so naturally I had to check it out. Largely set in a prison, Story of Ricky tells… well, the story of Ricky – a young man with seemingly superhuman strength and demonic powers, who fights back in increasingly brutal ways to try and help the underdogs. The absurd and outlandish death scenes in this film are a work of grotesque ‘Cronenbergian’ beauty, and never cease to surprise and entertain the viewer in their displays of gruesome practical effects work. An extremely fun genre-bender that certainly has to be one of the most inventive Hong Kong flicks of the 90s.

Robotrix (1991)

Directed by Jamie Luk

In the world of Robotrix a dying person’s consciousness and identity can be electrically transmitted to the body of a robot. When a psychotic rapist killer robot starts causing havoc with his political schemes, a trio of female ex-cop robots must track him down. As this is a Hong Kong flick from the early 90s with the category three rating adorned in that big red triangle on the poster, one can expect that everything in this cheesy martial arts sci-fi thriller will be dialled up to eleven. There are lots of hilariously bonkers set pieces, weird satirical dialogue, excessive gory violence, hilarious soft-core sex scenes and a couple uncomfortably disturbing rape scenes thrown in for disturbing measure… It’s certainly not for everyone, but it’s worth a watch for those who have already dipped their toes in the Hong Kong exploitation pool.

Naked Killer (1992)

Directed by Clarence Fok

Man-hating, martial arts trained, lesbian assassins display their kung-fu moves in this frequently bloody and superbly entertaining Hong Kong action flick from the early 90s. One of the few CAT 3 films to have passed through the British censors unscathed (probably because there’s actually a lack of sexual violence in this one for a nice change), Naked Killer is a true blast to sit through with its ludicrous mixture of violence, satire, cheese and crass humour. It’s definitely a highly recommended starting point for this kind of thing.

The Untold Story [Bunman] (1993)

Directed by Herman Yau / Danny Lee

From the director of Ebola Syndrome (Herman Yau) comes another certifiably insane work of extreme Hong Kong cinema – that also happens to star the charismatic Anthony Wong again. Bizarrely based on true events, The Untold Story tells the tale of an investigation into the disappearance of a family of eight and the recent new owner of the family’s restaurant (whose ‘BBQ pork buns’ are currently the talk of the town…). I don’t want to outright spoil anything with this film, but I highly recommend watching some other Hong Kong exploitation films first to see if you will be able to stomach this film’s disturbing mixture of pitch black comedy and mean-spirited violent content. You may very well feel like you’ll need a shower after this one…

Horrible High Heels (1996)

Directed by Chow Cheng / Chan Wai On

Starting with a rather bleak and unsettling series of opening credits shot in a slaughterhouse, the fascinatingly titled Horrible High Heels quickly gets down to grizzly business as a young woman and her drunk gambling-addicted father are brutally murdered by a masked assailant before being skinned to the bone. The masked assailant is a disgruntled leather-craftsman who decides to make a new kind of imitation-leather from human flesh, which he then proceeds to sell to a local shoe making shop… if that’s not a ludicrous enough premise to draw you in then I don’t know what is anymore.

The film manages mix genres so much that it actually kind of feels like two or three distinctly different films that have been smashed together in the editing room. There’s never a dull moment to be had in this depraved and weird blend of sadistic slasher-horror, family drama, softcore porno and gangster action flick. The hilariously over the top and prolonged sex-scenes, gruesome practical effects work and layers of action cheese were certainly entertaining highlights for me.

Human Pork Chop (2001)

Directed by Benny Chan Chi-Shun

For absurdly brilliant title alone this early 00s Hong Kong CAT III exploitation flick certainly rivals The Oily Maniac… however, a fun watch it is not…

Out of the ten or so Category III films I’ve seen so far now, this one also takes the award for the most mean-spirited and bleak, featuring much less humour and bizarre kookiness to balance out its cruel and sadistic plot. Told mostly in flashbacks through a thorough police interrogation (ala The Untold Story & Dr. Lamb), Human Pork Chop presents the (apparently true) story of a young woman who gets mixed up with a bunch of delinquent drug addicts and pimps who imprison and frequently torture her for their own sick amusement after she tries to take some money from them. Throughout the film’s barrage of cruel and disturbing games we are treated to some of the woman’s backstory through flashbacks, showing us that she has recently become pregnant and is on the verge of turning her life around.

It certainly succeeds in its aim to create a nihilistic and disturbing experience to make you feel as uncomfortable as possible… however it lacks a certain charismatic outrageousness to its violent nihilism that is present in other Hong Kong gems, such as Ebola Syndrome and The Untold Story.

General Exploitation / Cult Stuff:

The Girl Who Knew Too Much (1963)

Directed by Mario Bava

The Girl Who Knew Too Much is one of Mario Bava’s early black & white Gialo features and it is a tour de force in atmospheric style. Whilst I love the feel of Bava’s later films for their inspired use of colour, he still manages to create a visual aesthetic and presence that’s just as dynamic without a diverse colour palette to fall back upon. Playing with shadows, creative camera angles and murder mystery troupes, The Girl Who Knew Too Much is a brilliant and inspired tribute to Alfred Hitchcock films… Italian style.

Kill Baby Kill! (1966)

Directed by Mario Bava

For the second part of this Mario Bava double-dose, I picked out the gleefully named Kill Baby Kill which turned out to be a spectacular exercise in everything the director excels at; including a macabre but mysterious narrative and themes of an occult nature clashing with modernity. Bava also spikes the proceedings with a wonderfully surreal use of colour and lighting to punctuate the gothic set-designs. It will surely take a couple watches to fully soak it all up, but this might very well be up there with Black Sunday as one of the director’s most satisfying works.

Phenomena (1985)

Directed by Dario Argento

Dario Argento puts a neat supernatural twist on the ‘Gialo’ slasher formula in this mid 80s work starring Jennifer Connelly and Donald Pleasance. The plot follows a sleepwalking teenager (Connelly) – with a strange telepathic link to insects – as she befriends a wheelchair-bound entomologist (Pleasance) amidst a series of brutal murders happening around the grounds of her boarding school. Together (along with Pleasence’s Chimpanzee assistant) they attempt to uncover the identity of the serial killer by using the girl’s unique gifts.

It does seem to make a little more sense than some of Argento’s other works, but it still thankfully manages to retain the same phantasmagorical charm and gothic atmosphere that made Suspiria and Inferno so unique and dreamlike. There’s some impressive practical effects work on display for the film’s grisly death scenes, as well as a bizarre soundtrack that adds an element of kitsch fun to the already bonkers mixing bowl.

The Washing Machine (1993)

Directed by Ruggero Deodato

Cannibal Holocaust director Ruggero Deodato delivers the goods here (and I’m not just talking the ‘white electrical’ variety either…) in this bizarre 90s Gialo mystery that blends cheesy thrills, overt eroticism, splatter and neo-noir clichés into one wholesome package. It doesn’t make a whole lot of sense, but that really doesn’t matter since there is plenty of weird nonsense (including people having sex next to open refrigerators on more than one occasion… do these people not care for their electricity bills or the freshness of their refrigerated produce?) to divert your attention away from the scriptwriting. If you’re in the mood for some cheap but efficient Euro ‘Noir’ sleaze, then you can do far worse than giving The Washing Machine a quick ‘spin’.

Pieces (1982)

Directed by Juan
